<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Fair Value of Financial Instruments</I></B><br><br>
We record our cash equivalents and short-term investments at cost, which we
believe approximates their fair values. The estimated fair values of other
financial instruments, including debt and derivative instruments, have been
determined using available market information and valuation methodologies,
primarily discounted cash flow analyses and the Black-Scholes model.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Note 2. Marketable and Other Equity Securities</B><br>
<B><I>priceline.com Incorporated (priceline)</I></B><br><br>
We are party to an agreement with priceline under which we (1)&nbsp;provide ticket
inventory that may be sold through priceline&#146;s Internet-based e-commerce system
and (2)&nbsp;received certain equity interests in priceline. We are required to
provide priceline access to unpublished fares.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>2001</I><br>
At January&nbsp;1, 2001, our equity interests in priceline included (1)&nbsp;a warrant,
as amended, which is exercisable until November&nbsp;17, 2004, to purchase up to 4.7
million shares of priceline common stock for $4.72 per share (1999 Warrant) and
(2)&nbsp;six million shares of priceline Series&nbsp;A


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-19
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Convertible Preferred Stock (Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock). We recognized $61
million in income ratably from November&nbsp;1999 through November&nbsp;2002 related to
the original 1999 Warrant.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On February&nbsp;6, 2001, we and priceline agreed to restructure our investment in
priceline. We exchanged our six million shares of Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock for
(1)&nbsp;80,000 shares of priceline Series&nbsp;B Redeemable Preferred Stock (Series&nbsp;B
Preferred Stock) and (2)&nbsp;a warrant to purchase up to 26.9&nbsp;million shares of
priceline common stock for $2.97 per share (2001 Warrant).


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock (1)&nbsp;bears an annual per share dividend of
approximately 36 shares of priceline common stock; (2)&nbsp;has a liquidation
preference of $1,000 per share plus any dividends accrued or accumulated but
not yet paid (Liquidation Preference); (3)&nbsp;is subject to mandatory redemption
on February&nbsp;6, 2007, at a price per share equal to the Liquidation Preference;
and (4)&nbsp;is subject to redemption in whole, at the option of us or priceline, if
priceline completes any of certain business combination transactions (Optional
Redemption).


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">We may exercise the 2001 Warrant, in whole or in part, at any time prior to the
close of business on February&nbsp;6, 2007, unless all of the shares of Series&nbsp;B
Preferred Stock owned by us are redeemed in an Optional Redemption, in which
case we may not exercise the 2001 Warrant after the date of the Optional
Redemption. The exercise price may be paid by us only by the surrender of
shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock, valued at $1,000 per share.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The 2001 Warrant also provides that it will automatically be deemed exercised
if the closing sales price of priceline common stock exceeds $8.91 for 20
consecutive trading days. In that event, our rights in the shares of Series&nbsp;B
Preferred Stock necessary to pay the exercise price of the 2001 Warrant would
automatically be converted into the right to receive shares of priceline common
stock pursuant to the 2001 Warrant.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Based on an independent third-party appraisal, at February&nbsp;6, 2001, the fair
value of (1)&nbsp;the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was estimated to be $80&nbsp;million and
(2)&nbsp;the 2001 Warrant was estimated to be $46&nbsp;million. The total fair value of
these securities equaled the carrying amount of the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock,
including its conversion feature and accumulated dividends on the date the
Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock was exchanged for the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and the
2001 Warrant. Accordingly, we did not recognize a gain or loss on this
transaction.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During 2001, we (1)&nbsp;exercised the 2001 Warrant in part to purchase 18.4&nbsp;million
shares of priceline common stock, paying the exercise price by surrendering to
priceline 54,656 shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock; (2)&nbsp;sold 18.7&nbsp;million
shares of priceline common stock; and (3)&nbsp;received 986,491 shares of priceline
common stock as a dividend on the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. In our 2001
Consolidated Statement of Operations, we recognized (1)&nbsp;other income of $9
million, pretax, from the dividend and (2)&nbsp;a pretax gain of $4&nbsp;million from the
exercise of the 2001 Warrant and the sale of priceline common stock.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>2002</I><br>
During 2002, we (1)&nbsp;exercised the 2001 Warrant in part to purchase 4.0&nbsp;million
shares of priceline common stock, paying the exercise price by surrendering to
priceline 11,875 shares of


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-20
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock; (2)&nbsp;sold 3.9&nbsp;million shares of priceline common
stock; and (3)&nbsp;received 695,749 shares of priceline common stock as dividends
on the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. In our 2002 Consolidated Statement of
Operations, we recognized (1)&nbsp;a pretax loss of $3&nbsp;million from the exercise of
the 2001 Warrant and the sale of priceline common stock and (2)&nbsp;other income of
$2&nbsp;million, pretax, from the dividends.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><I>2003</I><br>
On June&nbsp;16, 2003, priceline effected a 1-for-6 reverse common stock split. As a
result of the stock split:


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The 1999 Warrant, as amended, was adjusted to (1)&nbsp;reduce from 4.7
million to approximately 779,000 the maximum number of shares we may
purchase by exercising that warrant and (2)&nbsp;increase from $4.72 to
$28.31 the per share purchase price of those shares.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The 2001 Warrant was adjusted to (1)&nbsp;reduce from 4.5&nbsp;million to
approximately 756,000 the maximum number of remaining shares we may
purchase by exercising that warrant; (2)&nbsp;increase from $2.97 to $17.81
the per share purchase price of those shares; and (3)&nbsp;increase from
$8.91 to $53.46 the closing sales price which priceline common stock
must exceed for 20 consecutive days for the 2001 Warrant to
automatically be deemed exercised.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock was adjusted to reduce its annual per
share dividend from approximately 36 shares to six shares of priceline
common stock.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The reverse stock split did not impact the carrying value of our equity
interests in priceline.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">During 2003, as adjusted for priceline&#146;s 1-for-6 reverse common stock split, we
(1)&nbsp;sold 423,640 shares of priceline common stock and (2)&nbsp;received 80,480
shares of priceline common stock. In our 2003 Consolidated Statements of
Operations, we recognized (1)&nbsp;a pretax gain of $5&nbsp;million from the sale of
priceline common stock; (2)&nbsp;other income of $1&nbsp;million, pretax, from the
dividends; and (3)&nbsp;an $8&nbsp;million writedown related to our priceline common
stock due to an other than temporary decline in the fair value of that stock.

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-21

</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock and priceline common stock are classified as
available-for-sale securities under SFAS 115 and are recorded in other
noncurrent assets on our Consolidated Balance Sheets. We did not own any shares
of priceline common stock at December&nbsp;31, 2003. The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock is
recorded at face value, which we believe approximates fair value. The 1999 and
2001 Warrants are recorded at fair value in other noncurrent assets on our
Consolidated Balance Sheets and any changes in fair value are recorded in other
income (expense)&nbsp;on our Consolidated Statements of Operations in accordance
with SFAS 133. See Note 1 for information about our accounting policy for
investments in debt and equity securities.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Republic Airways Holdings, Inc. (Republic)</I></B><br><br>
On June&nbsp;7, 2002, we entered into a contract carrier agreement with Chautauqua
Airlines, Inc. (Chautauqua), a regional air carrier that is a subsidiary of
Republic (see Note 9). In conjunction with this agreement, we received from
Republic (1)&nbsp;a warrant to purchase up to 1.5&nbsp;million shares of Republic common
stock for $12.50 per share (2002 Warrant); (2)&nbsp;a warrant to purchase up to 1.5
million shares of Republic common stock at a price per share equal to 95% of
the public offering price per share in Republic&#146;s initial public offering (IPO)
of common stock (IPO Warrant); (3)&nbsp;the right to purchase up to 5% of the shares
of common stock that Republic offers for sale in its IPO at a price per share
equal to the IPO price; and (4)&nbsp;the right to receive a warrant to purchase up
to an additional 60,000 shares of Republic common stock for each additional
aircraft Chautauqua operates for us above the 22 aircraft under the original
contract carrier agreement.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The 2002 Warrant is exercisable in whole or in part at any time until June&nbsp;7,
2012. The fair value of the 2002 Warrant on the date received was $11&nbsp;million,
and is being recognized on a straight-line basis over a five-year period in
other, net in operating revenues on our Consolidated Statement of Operations.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The IPO Warrant is exercisable in whole or in part at any time (1)&nbsp;beginning on
the closing date of Republic&#146;s IPO of common stock and (2)&nbsp;subject to earlier
cancellation if the contract carrier agreement is terminated in certain
circumstances, ending on the tenth anniversary of that closing date. We will
record the fair value of the IPO Warrant on the closing date of Republic&#146;s IPO
of common stock.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">In February and October&nbsp;2003, we amended our contract carrier agreement with
Chautauqua to increase from 22 to 34, and then from 34 to 39, respectively, the
number of aircraft Chautauqua will operate for us by the end of 2004 under that
agreement. As a result of these amendments, we received two new warrants, as
follows (2003 Warrants):

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

for (1) $12.50 per share, if the warrant is exercised prior to the
completion of Republic&#146;s IPO of common stock or (2)&nbsp;the price per share

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The 2003 Warrants are exercisable in whole or in part at any time until ten
years from their date of issue. The fair values of the 2003 Warrants on the
dates received were not material.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">The carrying value of the 2002 and 2003 Warrants was $18&nbsp;million at December
31, 2003. The carrying value of the 2002 Warrant was $10&nbsp;million at December
31, 2002. The 2002 and 2003 Warrants are accounted for in the same manner as
the priceline warrants described above and are included in other noncurrent
assets on our Consolidated Balance Sheets. The 2002 Warrant, the IPO Warrant,
the 2003 Warrants and the shares of Republic common stock underlying these
securities are not registered under the Securities Act of 1933; however, we
have certain demand and piggyback registration rights relating to the
underlying shares of Republic common stock.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Other</I></B><br><br>
During 2001, we sold our equity interests in SkyWest, Inc., the parent company
of SkyWest Airlines, Inc. (SkyWest), and Equant, N.V., an international data
services company. We recognized pretax gains of $111&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million,
respectively, on these transactions. These gains are recorded in our 2001
Consolidated Statement of Operations in gain (loss)&nbsp;from sale of investments,
net.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Note 3. Risk Management</B><br>
<B><I>Aircraft Fuel Price Risk</I></B><br><br>
Our results of operations can be significantly impacted by changes in the price
of aircraft fuel. To manage this risk, we periodically purchase options and
other similar derivative instruments and enter into forward contracts for the
purchase of fuel. These contracts may have maturities of up to 36&nbsp;months. We
may hedge up to 80% of our expected fuel requirements on a 12-month rolling
basis. See Note 4 for additional information about our fuel hedge contracts. We
do not enter into fuel hedge contracts for speculative purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Interest Rate Risk</I></B><br><br>
Our exposure to market risk due to changes in interest rates primarily relates
to our long-term debt obligations, cash portfolio, and pension, postemployment
and postretirement benefits. Market risk associated with our long-term debt
relates to the potential change in fair value resulting from a change in
interest rates as well as the potential increase in interest we would pay on
variable rate debt. At December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, approximately 34% and 26%,
respectively, of our total debt was variable rate debt. Market risk associated
with our cash portfolio relates to the potential change in our earnings
resulting from a decrease in interest rates. Pension, postemployment and
postretirement benefits risk relates to the potential changes in our benefit
obligations, funding and expenses from a change in interest rates (see Note
11).


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">From time to time, we may enter into interest rate swap agreements, provided
that the notional amount of these transactions does not exceed 50% of our
long-term debt. See Note 4 for additional information about our interest rate
swap agreements. We do not enter into interest rate swap agreements for
speculative purposes.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-23
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Foreign Currency Exchange Risk</I></B><br><br>
We are subject to foreign currency exchange risk because we have revenues and
expenses denominated in foreign currencies, primarily the euro, the British
pound and the Canadian dollar. To manage exchange rate risk, we attempt to
execute both our international revenue and expense transactions in the same
foreign currency, to the extent practicable. From time to time, we may also
enter into foreign currency options and forward contracts with maturities of up
to 12&nbsp;months. We did not have any foreign currency hedge contracts at December
31, 2003 or 2002. We do not enter into foreign currency hedge contracts for
speculative purposes.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Credit Risk</I></B><br><br>
To manage credit risk associated with our aircraft fuel price, interest rate
and foreign currency exchange risk management programs, we select
counterparties based on their credit ratings and limit our exposure to any one
counterparty under defined guidelines. We also monitor the market position of
these programs and our relative market position with each counterparty. The
credit exposure related to these programs was not significant at December&nbsp;31,
2003 and 2002.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Our accounts receivable are generated largely from the sale of passenger
airline tickets and cargo transportation services. The majority of these sales
are processed through major credit card companies, resulting in accounts
receivable which are generally short-term in duration. We also have receivables
from the sale of mileage credits to partners, such as credit card companies,
hotels and car rental agencies, that participate in our SkyMiles program. We
believe that the credit risk associated with these receivables is minimal and
that the allowance for uncollectible accounts that we have provided is
appropriate.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Self-Insurance Risk</I></B><br><br>
We self-insure a portion of our losses from claims related to workers&#146;
compensation, environmental issues, property damage, medical insurance for
employees and general liability. Losses are accrued based on an estimate of the
ultimate aggregate liability for claims incurred, using independent actuarial
reviews based on standard industry practices and our actual experience. A
portion of our projected workers&#146; compensation liability is secured with
restricted cash collateral (see Note 1).


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Note 4. Derivative Instruments</B><br><br>
On July&nbsp;1, 2000, we adopted SFAS 133, as amended, which requires us to record
all derivative instruments on our Consolidated Balance Sheets at fair value and
to recognize certain changes in these fair values in our Consolidated
Statements of Operations. SFAS 133 impacts the accounting for our fuel hedging
program, our interest rate hedging program and our holdings of equity warrants
and other similar rights in certain companies.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-24
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Fuel Hedging Program</I></B><br><br>
Because there is not a readily available market for derivatives in aircraft
fuel, we use heating and crude oil derivative contracts to manage our exposure
to changes in aircraft fuel prices. Changes in the fair value of these
contracts (fuel hedge contracts) are highly effective at offsetting changes in
aircraft fuel prices.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, our fuel hedge contracts had a fair value of $97&nbsp;million,
which was recorded in prepaid expenses and other, with unrealized effective
gains of $34&nbsp;million, net of tax, recorded in accumulated other comprehensive
loss on our Consolidated Balance Sheet. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, our fuel hedge
contracts had a fair value of $73&nbsp;million, $68&nbsp;million of which was recorded in
prepaid expenses and other and $5&nbsp;million of which was recorded in noncurrent
assets, with unrealized effective gains of $29&nbsp;million, net of tax, recorded in
accumulated other comprehensive loss on our Consolidated Balance Sheet. See
Note 1 for information about our accounting policy for fuel hedge contracts.
See Note 22 for information regarding the early settlement of our fuel hedge
contracts.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B><I>Interest Rate Hedging Program</I></B><br><br>
To manage our interest rate exposure, in July&nbsp;2002, we entered into two
interest rate swap agreements relating to our (1) $300&nbsp;million principal amount
of unsecured Series&nbsp;C Medium-Term Notes due March&nbsp;15, 2004, which pay interest
at a fixed rate of 6.65% per year and (2) $500&nbsp;million principal amount of
unsecured Notes due December&nbsp;15, 2005, which pay interest at a fixed rate of
7.70% per year. Under the first interest rate swap agreement, we paid the
London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR)&nbsp;plus a margin per year in exchange for
the right to receive 6.65% per year on a notional amount of $300&nbsp;million until
March&nbsp;15, 2004. Under the second agreement, we paid LIBOR plus a margin per
year in exchange for the right to receive 7.70% per year on a notional amount
of $500&nbsp;million until December&nbsp;15, 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">On May&nbsp;9, 2003, we settled these interest rate swap agreements prior to their
expiration. As a result, we received $27&nbsp;million, including $7&nbsp;million
previously recognized as adjustments to interest expense under the terms of the
swap agreements. These swaps were accounted for as fair value hedges of debt in
accordance with SFAS 133. At the date of settlement, the fair value
adjustments to the previously underlying debt related to the interest rate
swaps totaled $20&nbsp;million. These adjustments are being recognized in accordance
with SFAS 133 as an adjustment to interest expense over the remaining term of
the previously underlying debt. A portion of these fair value adjustments were
recognized as a part of the gain on extinguishment of a portion of the
previously hedged debt (see Note 6).


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">At December&nbsp;31, 2002, our interest rate swap agreements had a fair value of $21
million, which was recorded in other noncurrent assets on our Consolidated
Balance Sheet. In accordance with



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-25
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">fair value hedge accounting, the carrying
value of our long-term debt at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002 included $8&nbsp;million
and $21&nbsp;million, respectively, of fair value adjustments. See Note 1 for
information about our accounting policy for interest rate swap agreements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Equity Warrants and Other Similar Rights</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We own equity warrants and other similar rights in certain companies, primarily
priceline and Republic. The total fair value of these rights was $30&nbsp;million
and $14&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively. See Notes 1 and 2
for information about our accounting policy for and ownership of these rights,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 5. Goodwill and Intangible Assets</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;1, 2002, we adopted SFAS 142, which requires that we discontinue the
amortization of goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful
lives. Accordingly, we now apply a fair value-based impairment test to the net
book value of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets. See Note 1 for
information about our accounting policy for the impairment tests of goodwill
and other intangible assets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The adoption of SFAS 142 decreased our operating expenses on our Consolidated
Statements of Operations by approximately $60&nbsp;million, net of tax, for each of
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, due to the discontinuance of
amortization of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets. During the
June 2002 quarter, we completed our transitional goodwill impairment test,
which indicated no impairment at the date of adoption of SFAS 142.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following table reconciles our reported net loss and loss per share to
adjusted net loss and loss per share as if the non-amortization provisions of
SFAS 142 had been applied to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001:
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-26</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">During the March 2002 quarter, we completed the required initial test of
potential impairment of indefinite-lived intangible assets, other than
goodwill; that test indicated no impairment at the date of adoption of SFAS
142. The following table presents information about our intangible assets,
other than goodwill, at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002:

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, we performed the required annual impairment test of our
goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets; that test indicated no
impairment.
</FONT>

    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Our secured debt is collateralized by first mortgage liens on a total of
320 aircraft (71 B-737-800, 41 B-757-200, two
B-767-300, 38 B-767-300ER, 21 B-767-400, eight B-777-200, and 139
CRJ-100/200/700) delivered new to us from March 1992 through December 2003.
In addition, certain debt is secured by 96 spare mainline aircraft engines
(Engine Collateral), which constitute substantially all the spare mainline
aircraft engines currently owned by us, and by a substantial portion of the
mainline aircraft spare parts owned by us (Spare Parts Collateral). These
aircraft, engines and spare parts had an aggregate net book value of
approximately $10.6&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2003.</FONT></TD>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have available to us long-term, secured financing commitments from a third
party that we may elect to use for a substantial portion of the regional jet
aircraft delivered to ASA and Comair through 2004. Borrowings under these
commitments would bear interest at a rate determined by reference to ten-year
U.S. Treasury Notes plus a margin, and would have various repayment dates. Our
election to use these commitments would result in the refinancing of
approximately $300&nbsp;million of our 2004 maturities included in the table above.
Other than these commitments, we do not have any undrawn lines of credit.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Boston Airport Terminal Project</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">During 2001, we entered into lease and financing agreements with the
Massachusetts Port Authority (Massport) for the redevelopment and expansion of
Terminal A at Boston&#146;s Logan International Airport. The completion of this
project will enable us to consolidate all of our domestic operations at that
airport into one location. Construction began in the June 2002 quarter
and is expected to be completed during 2005. Project costs will be funded with
$498&nbsp;million in proceeds from Special Facilities Revenue Bonds issued by
Massport on August&nbsp;16, 2001. We agreed to pay the debt service on the bonds
under a long-term lease agreement with Massport and issued a guarantee to the
bond trustee covering the payment of the debt service on the bonds. For
additional information about these bonds, see the debt table above. Because we
have issued a guarantee of the debt service on the bonds, we have included the
bonds, as well as the related bond proceeds, on our Consolidated Balance
Sheets. The bonds are reflected in noncurrent
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-29</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">liabilities and the related
remaining proceeds, which are held in trust, are reflected as restricted
investments in other assets on our Consolidated Balance Sheets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Letter Of Credit Enhanced Municipal Bonds</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, there were outstanding $397&nbsp;million aggregate principal
amount of tax-exempt municipal bonds (Bonds) enhanced by letters of credit,
including:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">$295&nbsp;million principal amount of bonds issued by the Development
Authority of Clayton County (Clayton Authority) to refinance the
construction cost of certain facilities leased to us at
Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport. We pay debt service
on these bonds pursuant to loan agreements between us and the Clayton
Authority; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">$102&nbsp;million principal amount of bonds issued by other
municipalities to refinance the construction cost of certain facilities
leased to us at Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport,
Salt Lake City International Airport and Tampa International Airport.
We pay debt service on these bonds pursuant to long-term lease
agreements (see Note 7).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Bonds (1)&nbsp;have scheduled maturities between 2029 and 2035; (2)&nbsp;currently
bear interest at a variable rate that is determined weekly; and (3)&nbsp;may be
tendered for purchase by their holders on seven days&#146; notice. Tendered Bonds
are remarketed at prevailing interest rates.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Principal and interest on the Bonds are currently paid through drawings on
irrevocable, direct-pay letters of credit totaling $404&nbsp;million issued by GECC.
In addition, the purchase price of tendered Bonds that cannot be remarketed are
paid by drawings on these letters of credit. The GECC letters of credit, which
replaced similar letters of credit issued by a third party, expire on May&nbsp;20,
2008.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Pursuant to an agreement between us and GECC (Reimbursement Agreement), we are
required to reimburse GECC for drawings on the letters of credit. Our
reimbursement obligation to GECC is secured by nine B-767-400 and three
B-777-200 aircraft (LOC Aircraft Collateral) and 96 spare mainline engines
owned by us. This collateral also secures other obligations we have to GECC, as
discussed in the table above.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">If a drawing under a letter of credit is made to pay the purchase price of
Bonds tendered for purchase and not remarketed, our resulting reimbursement
obligation to GECC will bear interest at a base rate or three-month LIBOR plus
a margin. The principal amount of the reimbursement obligation will be repaid
quarterly through May&nbsp;20, 2008.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">GECC has the right to cause a mandatory tender for purchase of all Bonds and
terminate the letters of credit if an event of default occurs or if a minimum
collateral value test (Collateral Value Test) is not satisfied on May&nbsp;19, 2006.
We will not satisfy the Collateral Value Test if (1)&nbsp;the appraised market
value of the LOC Aircraft Collateral on March&nbsp;20, 2006 is less than two times
the aggregate amount of the outstanding letters of credit plus any other
amounts payable by us under the Reimbursement Agreement (Aggregate Obligations)
and (2)&nbsp;within 60&nbsp;days
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-30</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">thereafter, we have not either provided additional
collateral to GECC in the form of cash or aircraft or caused a reduction in the
Aggregate Obligations such that the Collateral Value Test is satisfied.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Unless the GECC letters of credit are extended in a timely manner, we will be
required to purchase the Bonds on May&nbsp;15, 2008, five days prior to the
expiration of the letters of credit. In this circumstance, we could seek, but
there is no assurance that we would be able, to (1)&nbsp;sell the Bonds without
credit enhancement at then-prevailing fixed interest rates or (2)&nbsp;replace the
expiring letters of credit with new letters of credit from an alternate credit
provider and remarket the Bonds.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We may terminate the GECC letters of credit, and repay any outstanding
obligations under the Reimbursement Agreement, at our election prior to
maturity, subject to certain prepayment fees if such action occurs before May
20, 2005.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Convertible Senior Notes (8.00% Notes)</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In June 2003, we issued $350&nbsp;million principal amount of 8.00% Notes due 2023.
Holders may convert their 8.00% Notes into shares of our common stock at a
conversion rate of 35.7143 shares of common stock per $1,000 principal amount
of 8.00% Notes, subject to adjustment in certain circumstances, which is
equivalent to a conversion price of approximately $28.00 per share of common
stock, if:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">during any calendar quarter after June&nbsp;30, 2003, the last reported
sale price of our common stock for at least 20 trading days during the
period of 30 consecutive trading days ending on the last trading day of
the immediately preceding calendar quarter is greater than or equal to
130% of the conversion price per share of our common stock;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">the trading price of the 8.00% Notes falls below a specified threshold;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">we call the 8.00% Notes for redemption; or</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">specified corporate transactions occur.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We may redeem all or some of the 8.00% Notes for cash at any time after June&nbsp;5,
2008, at a redemption price equal to the principal amount of the 8.00% Notes to
be redeemed plus any accrued and unpaid interest.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Holders may require us to repurchase their 8.00% Notes for cash on June&nbsp;3,
2008, 2013 and 2018, or in other specified circumstances involving the
exchange, conversion or acquisition of all or substantially all of our common
stock, at a purchase price equal to the principal amount of the 8.00% Notes to
be purchased plus any accrued and unpaid interest. At December&nbsp;31, 2003,
12,500,005 shares of common stock were reserved for issuance for the conversion
of the 8.00% Notes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>ESOP Notes</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We guarantee the ESOP Notes issued by the Delta Family-Care Savings Plan.
During 2002, we terminated the letter of credit used to make required payments
of principal, interest and make-whole premium on the ESOP Notes. As a result of
this action, each holder of ESOP Notes had
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-31</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">two opportunities to require us to
purchase their ESOP Notes. During 2002, we purchased ESOP Notes for $215
million, covering $169&nbsp;million principal amount of ESOP Notes, $4&nbsp;million of
accrued interest and $42&nbsp;million of make-whole premium. During 2003, we
purchased additional ESOP Notes for $91&nbsp;million, covering $72&nbsp;million principal
amount of ESOP Notes, $4&nbsp;million of accrued interest and $15&nbsp;million of
make-whole premium. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, $18&nbsp;million principal amount of
ESOP Notes was held by third parties.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We recognized losses of $15&nbsp;million and $42&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively, for the make-whole premiums related
to these extinguishments of debt. These losses were recorded in other income
(expense)&nbsp;on our Consolidated Statements of Operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Debt Exchange Offer</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In September 2003, we completed a debt exchange offer relating to $300&nbsp;million
principal amount of our 6.65% Series&nbsp;C Medium-Term Notes due 2004 (2004 Notes),
and $500&nbsp;million principal amount of our 7.70% Senior Notes due 2005 (2005
Notes). Under the exchange offer, qualified institutional buyers could elect
to exchange (1)&nbsp;for each $1,000 principal amount of 2004 Notes tendered, $650
cash and $409.50 principal amount of new 10% Senior Notes due August&nbsp;15, 2008
(2008 Notes), and (2)&nbsp;for each $1,000 principal amount of 2005 Notes tendered,
$1,120 principal amount of new 2008 Notes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Eligible holders elected to exchange $64&nbsp;million principal amount of the 2004
Notes and $198&nbsp;million principal amount of the 2005 Notes. We paid a total of
$47&nbsp;million in cash (including $5&nbsp;million in accrued interest) and issued an
aggregate of $248&nbsp;million principal amount of 2008 Notes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The exchange offer qualified as a debt extinguishment and, accordingly, we
recorded the issuance of the 2008 Notes at a fair value of $211&nbsp;million, which
reflects a $37&nbsp;million original issue discount. This discount will be amortized
to interest expense through August&nbsp;15, 2008. Of the $47&nbsp;million payment, we
recorded $42&nbsp;million as a payment on long-term debt and capital lease
obligations and $5&nbsp;million as a change in certain assets and liabilities, net
on our 2003 Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows. As a result of this
transaction, we also recorded a $15&nbsp;million gain ($9&nbsp;million net of tax) on
extinguishment of debt in other income (expense)&nbsp;on our 2003 Consolidated
Statement of Operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Other Financing Arrangements</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;31, 2002, we entered into a facility to finance, on a secured basis
at the time of acquisition, certain future deliveries of regional jet aircraft.
At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the total borrowings outstanding under this facility, as
amended, were $449&nbsp;million. Borrowings under this
facility (1)&nbsp;are due between 366&nbsp;days and 18&nbsp;months after the date of borrowing
(subject to earlier repayment if certain longer-term financing is obtained for
these aircraft) and (2)&nbsp;bear interest at LIBOR plus a margin.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Covenants</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our credit facilities do not contain any negative financial covenants. As
discussed above, our Reimbursement Agreement with GECC includes the Collateral
Value Test.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">As is customary in the airline industry, our aircraft lease and financing
agreements require that we maintain certain levels of insurance coverage,
including war-risk insurance. We were in compliance with these requirements at
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002. See Note 19 for additional information on war-risk
insurance currently provided by the U.S. government under the Air
Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-32</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 7. Lease Obligations</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We lease aircraft, airport terminal and maintenance facilities, ticket offices
and other property and equipment from third parties. Rental expense for
operating leases, which is recorded on a straight-line basis over the life of
the lease, totaled $1.3&nbsp;billion for each year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and
2001. Amounts due under capital leases are recorded as liabilities on our
Consolidated Balance Sheets. Our interest in assets acquired under capital
leases is recorded as property and equipment on our Consolidated Balance
Sheets. Amortization of assets recorded under capital leases is included in
depreciation and amortization expense on our Consolidated Statements of
Operations. Our leases do not include residual value guarantees.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following table summarizes, as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, our minimum rental
commitments under capital leases and noncancelable operating leases with
initial or remaining terms in excess of one year:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We expect to receive approximately $130&nbsp;million under noncancelable sublease
agreements. This expected sublease income is not reflected as a reduction in
the total minimum rental commitments under operating leases in the table above.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, we operated 309 aircraft under operating leases and 39
aircraft under capital leases. These leases have remaining terms ranging from
three months to 14&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Certain municipalities have issued special facilities revenue bonds to build or
improve airport and maintenance facilities leased to us. The facility lease
agreements require us to make rental payments sufficient to pay principal and
interest on the bonds. The above table includes $1.7&nbsp;billion of operating lease
rental commitments for such payments.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-33</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 8. Sale of Receivables</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We were party to an agreement, as amended, under which we sold a defined pool
of our accounts receivable, on a revolving basis, through a special-purpose,
wholly owned subsidiary, which then sold an undivided interest in the
receivables to a third party. In accordance with SFAS 140, &#147;Accounting for
Transfers and Servicing of Financial Assets and Extinguishments of Liabilities&#148;
(SFAS 140), the subsidiary was not consolidated in our Consolidated Financial
Statements. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had a subordinated promissory note with a
principal amount of $67&nbsp;million from the subsidiary; this note was included in
accounts receivable on our 2002 Consolidated Balance Sheet. Additionally, our
investment in the subsidiary, which represented our funding of that entity,
totaled $117&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002, and was recorded in investments in
associated companies on our Consolidated Balance Sheet.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">This agreement terminated on its scheduled expiration date of March&nbsp;31, 2003.
As a result, on April&nbsp;2, 2003, we paid $250&nbsp;million, which represented the
total amount owed to the third party by the subsidiary, and subsequently
collected the related receivables.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 9. Purchase Commitments and Contingencies</B>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The table above includes our payments to purchase from the manufacturer 11
B-737-800 aircraft, which we have entered into a definitive agreement to sell
to a third party immediately following delivery of these aircraft to us in
2005. This transaction will reduce our commitments by approximately $460
million through 2005. We also granted the third party an option to purchase up
to 10 additional B-737-800 aircraft scheduled for delivery to us in 2006.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Additionally, as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, we had deferred delivery of one
B-737-800 aircraft, and plan to exercise our right to defer delivery of an
additional seven B-737-800 aircraft from 2005 to 2008. This transaction will
defer approximately $300&nbsp;million of our commitments through 2005 to later years
in the table above.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Contract Carrier Agreements</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have contract carrier agreements with three regional air carriers, Atlantic
Coast Airlines (ACA), SkyWest and Chautauqua. Under these agreements, ACA,
SkyWest and Chautauqua operate certain of their aircraft using our flight code;
we schedule those aircraft and sell the seats
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-34</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">on those flights; and we retain the related revenues. We pay those airlines an
amount, as defined in the applicable agreement, which is based on an annual
redetermination of their cost of operating those flights and other factors
intended to approximate market rates for those services. Our contract carrier
agreements with ACA and SkyWest expire in 2010, and our agreement with
Chautauqua expires in 2012.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The following table shows the total number of aircraft and available seat miles
(ASMs) operated for us by ACA, SkyWest and Chautauqua under, and our expenses
related to, the contract carrier agreements, for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2003, 2002 and 2001:

    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">The 123 aircraft operated for us at December&nbsp;31, 2003
include 30 aircraft operated by ACA,
59 aircraft operated by SkyWest and 34 aircraft operated by Chautauqua.

by the end of 2004.</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">During 2004, we expect to incur a total of approximately $890&nbsp;million in
expenses related to our contract carrier agreements with these airlines. See
Note 1 for information about our accounting policy for revenues and expenses
related to our contract carrier agreements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We may terminate the ACA and SkyWest agreements without cause at any time by
giving the airlines certain advance notice. If we terminate the ACA agreement
without cause, ACA has the right to (1)&nbsp;assign to us leased aircraft that it
operates for us, provided we are able to continue the leases on the same
financial terms ACA had prior to the assignment and (2)&nbsp;require us to purchase,
at fair value, aircraft that ACA operates for us and owns at the time of the
termination. If we terminate the SkyWest agreement without cause, SkyWest has
the right to assign to us leased regional jet aircraft which it operates for
us, provided we are able to continue the leases on the same terms SkyWest had
prior to the assignment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We may terminate the Chautauqua
agreement, as amended,  without cause at any time after November 2008 by giving the airline certain advance notice. If we terminate the
Chautauqua agreement without cause, Chautauqua has the right to (1)&nbsp;assign to
us leased aircraft that it operates for us, provided we are able to continue
the leases on the same terms Chautauqua had prior to the assignment and (2)
require us to purchase or sublease any of the aircraft that it owns and
operates for us at the time of the termination. If we are required to purchase
aircraft owned by Chautauqua, the purchase price would be equal to the amount
necessary to (1)&nbsp;reimburse Chautauqua for the equity it provided to purchase
the aircraft and (2)&nbsp;repay in full any debt outstanding at such time that is
not being assumed in connection with such purchase. If we are required to
sublease aircraft owned by Chautauqua, the sublease would have (1)&nbsp;a rate equal
to the debt payments of Chautauqua for the debt financing of the aircraft
calculated as if 90% of the aircraft was debt financed by Chautauqua and (2)
specified other terms and conditions.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-35</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ACA has announced plans to begin operating in November 2004 a new low-fare
airline using jet aircraft with more than 70 seats. Our collective bargaining
agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association, International (ALPA)&nbsp;prohibits
contract carrier codeshare arrangements with domestic carriers such as ACA if
the contract carrier operates aircraft with more than 70 seats. As discussed
above, we have the right to terminate the ACA agreement without cause, in which
case ACA has the right to require us to assume the leases on leased aircraft,
or purchase owned aircraft, that ACA operates for us. ACA currently operates 30
leased Fairchild Dornier FRJ-328 regional jet aircraft for us. If we are
required to assume the leases on these aircraft in November 2004, we estimate
that the total remaining operating lease payments would be approximately $300
million. These payments would be made over the remaining terms of the aircraft
leases, which are approximately 13&nbsp;years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We estimate that the total fair value, at December&nbsp;31, 2003, of the aircraft
that SkyWest or Chautauqua could assign to us or require that we purchase if we
terminate without cause our contract carrier agreements with those airlines is
approximately $630&nbsp;million and $450&nbsp;million, respectively. The actual amount
that we may be required to pay in these circumstances may be materially
different from these estimates.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Legal Contingencies</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We are involved in legal proceedings relating to antitrust matters, employment
practices, environmental issues and other matters concerning our business. We
are also a defendant in numerous lawsuits arising out of the terrorist attacks
of September&nbsp;11, 2001. We cannot reasonably estimate the potential loss for
certain legal proceedings because, for example, the litigation is in its early
stages or the plaintiff does not specify the damages being sought. Although the
ultimate outcome of our legal proceedings cannot be predicted with certainty,
we believe that the resolution of these actions will not have a material
adverse effect on our Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Other Contingencies</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Regional Airports Improvement Corporation (RAIC)</I><br><br>
We are obligated under a facilities sublease with the RAIC to pay the bond
trustee rent in an amount sufficient to pay the debt service on $47&nbsp;million in
Facilities Sublease Revenue Bonds; these bonds were issued in 1985 to finance
the construction of certain airport and terminal facilities we lease at Los
Angeles International Airport. We also provide a guarantee to the bond trustee
covering payment of the debt service.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>General Indemnifications</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We are the lessee under many real estate leases. It is common in these
commercial lease transactions for us, as the lessee, to agree to indemnify the
lessor and other related third parties for tort, environmental and other
liabilities that arise out of or relate to our use or occupancy of the leased
premises. This type of indemnity would typically make us responsible to
indemnified parties for liabilities arising out of the conduct of, among
others, contractors, licensees and invitees at or in connection with the use or
occupancy of the leased premises. This indemnity often extends to related
liabilities arising from the negligence of the indemnified parties, but
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-36</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">usually excludes any liabilities caused by either their sole or gross
negligence and their willful misconduct.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our aircraft and other equipment lease and financing agreements typically
contain provisions requiring us, as the lessee or obligor, to indemnify the
other parties to those agreements, including certain related parties, against
virtually any liabilities that might arise from the condition, use or operation
of the aircraft or such other equipment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We believe that our insurance would cover most of our exposure to such
liabilities and related indemnities associated with the types of lease and
financing agreements described above, including real estate leases.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Certain of our aircraft and other financing transactions include provisions
which require us to make payments to preserve an expected economic return to
the lenders if that economic return is diminished due to certain changes in law
or regulations. In certain of these financing transactions, we also bear the
risk of certain changes in tax laws that would subject payments to non-U.S.
lenders to withholding taxes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We cannot reasonably estimate our potential future payments under the
indemnities and related provisions described above because we cannot predict
when and under what circumstances these provisions may be triggered.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Employees Under Collective Bargaining Agreements</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, we had a total of approximately 70,600 full-time
equivalent employees. Approximately 18% of these employees, including all of
our pilots, are represented by labor unions. ASA is in collective bargaining
negotiations with ALPA and the Association of Flight Attendants (AFA), which
represent ASA&#146;s approximately 1,450 pilots and 800 flight attendants,
respectively. ASA&#146;s collective bargaining agreements with ALPA and AFA became
amendable in September 2002 and September 2003, respectively. The outcome of
these collective bargaining negotiations cannot presently be determined.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Delta&#146;s collective bargaining agreement with ALPA becomes amendable on May&nbsp;1,
2005. The agreement generally provides that no pilot on the seniority list as
of July&nbsp;1, 2001 may be furloughed unless the furlough is caused by a
circumstance beyond our control, as defined in the agreement. Therefore, if we
reduce the number of flights in our schedule for reasons other than a
circumstance beyond our control, as defined in the agreement, we may be
required to pay unutilized pilots their full salary and benefits. If we
furlough pilots due to a circumstance beyond our control, we are only obligated
to remit furlough pay and to provide or pay for certain other benefits for a
limited period until the pilots are recalled. We have been involved in
arbitration regarding whether the agreement permits furloughs in particular
circumstances.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Planned Sale of Aircraft</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In conjunction with our agreement to sell 11 B-737-800 aircraft to a third
party immediately after those aircraft are delivered to us by the manufacturer
in 2005, we have agreed to pay the third party, for a designated period with
respect to each of the 11 B-737-800 aircraft, an amount equal
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-37</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">to the excess, if any, of a specified rate over the rate at which the third
party leases the aircraft to another party. The maximum undiscounted amount we
could be required to pay for all 11 aircraft totals approximately $70&nbsp;million.
While we cannot predict with certainty whether we will be required to make a
payment under this provision, we believe that the possibility of this event is
not likely due to the current and estimated future marketability of these
aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Other</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We have certain contracts for goods and services that require us to pay a
penalty, acquire inventory specific to us or purchase contract specific
equipment, as defined by each respective contract, if we terminate the contract
without cause prior to its expiration date. These obligations are contingent
upon whether we terminate the contract without cause prior to its expiration
date; therefore, no obligation would exist unless such a termination were to
occur.
</FONT>

purposes and income tax purposes (see Note 1 for information about our
accounting policy for income taxes). The following table shows significant
components of our deferred tax assets and liabilities at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, we had $346&nbsp;million of federal alternative minimum tax
(AMT)&nbsp;credit carryforward, which does not expire. We also had federal and state
net operating loss
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-38</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">carryforwards of approximately $4.9&nbsp;billion, pretax, at December&nbsp;31, 2003,
substantially all of which will not begin to expire until 2022.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In accordance with SFAS 109, deferred tax assets should be reduced by a
valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some portion or all of
the deferred tax assets will not be realized. The future realization of our net
deferred tax assets depends on the availability of sufficient future taxable
income. In making this determination, we considered all available positive and
negative evidence and made certain assumptions. We considered, among other
things, the overall business environment; our historical earnings, including
our significant pretax losses incurred during the last three years; our
industry&#146;s historically cyclical periods of earnings and losses; and our
outlook for future years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We performed this analysis as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 and determined that there
was sufficient positive evidence to conclude that it is more likely than not
that our net deferred tax assets will be realized. We will assess the need for
a deferred tax asset valuation allowance on an ongoing basis considering
factors such as those mentioned above as well as other relevant criteria.
Changes in our assumptions may have a material impact on our Consolidated
Financial Statements.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-39</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 11. Employee Benefit Plans</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We sponsor qualified and non-qualified defined
benefit pension plans, defined
contribution pension plans, healthcare plans, and disability and survivorship
plans for eligible employees and
retirees, and their eligible family members. We reserve the right to modify or
terminate these plans as to all participants and beneficiaries at any time,
except as restricted by the Internal Revenue Code or the Employee Retirement
Income Security Act (ERISA).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our qualified defined benefit pension plans meet or exceed ERISA&#146;s minimum
funding requirements as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. Our non-qualified plans are
funded primarily with current assets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We regularly evaluate ways to better manage employee benefits and control
costs. Any changes to the plans or assumptions used to estimate future benefits
could have a significant effect on the amount of the reported obligation and
future annual expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Pension and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We sponsor both funded and nonfunded noncontributory defined benefit pension
plans that cover substantially all of our employees. The plans generally
provide benefits based on years of service and final average salary. However,
as announced in the December 2002 quarter and effective July&nbsp;1, 2003, the
existing plan for employees not covered by a collective bargaining agreement
(Non-contract employees) was converted to a cash balance plan with a seven year
transition period. During the transition period, eligible Non-contract
employees receive the greater of the old final average salary benefit or the
new cash balance benefit. Generally, the new cash balance benefit formula
provides for an annual pay credit of 6% of eligible pay plus accrued interest.
Participants in the plan on July&nbsp;1, 2003, may be eligible for additional pay
credits of 2% or 2.75%, depending on their age and service as of that date.
Non-contract employees hired on or after July&nbsp;1, 2003 are covered by the cash
balance plan only. Effective July&nbsp;1, 2010, all covered employees earn the cash
balance benefit only.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We also sponsor medical plans that provide benefits to substantially all Delta
retirees and their eligible dependents. Benefits are funded from our current
assets. Plan benefits are subject to copayments, deductibles and other limits
as described in the plans. Non-contract employees hired on or after July&nbsp;1, 2003 are not
eligible for company provided postretirement medical coverage, although they
may purchase coverage at full cost.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We use a September&nbsp;30 measurement date for all our benefit plans. As discussed
above, during the December 2002 quarter, we announced the implementation of and
migration to a cash balance pension plan, as well as changes to eligibility
requirements for postretirement medical coverage for Non-contract employees. As a
result of these changes and the 2002 workforce reductions (see Note 15), we
remeasured a portion of our benefit obligations on October&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-40</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">During December 2003, we recorded a $212&nbsp;million non-cash charge on our Consolidated
Statement of Operations related to our pilots&#146; defined benefit pension plan due
to a significant increase in pilot retirements. We recorded this charge in
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;88, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for Settlements and
Curtailments of Defined Benefit Pension Plans and for Termination Benefits&#148;
(SFAS 88). SFAS 88 requires settlement accounting if the cost of all
settlements, including lump sum retirement benefits paid, in a year exceeds the
total of the service and interest cost components of pension expense for the
same period.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The special termination benefits and
curtailment loss (gain) reflected in the table
above relate to the workforce reduction programs offered to certain of our
employees in 2002. See Note 15 for additional information about our 2002
workforce reduction programs.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, we recorded a non-cash charge to accumulated
other comprehensive loss to recognize a portion of our additional minimum
pension liability in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;87, &#147;Employers&#146; Accounting for
Pensions&#148; (SFAS 87). SFAS 87 requires that this liability be recognized at
year end in an amount equal to the amount by which the accumulated benefit
obligation (ABO)&nbsp;exceeds the fair value of the defined benefit pension plan
assets. The additional minimum pension liability was recorded by recognizing an
intangible asset to the extent of any unrecognized prior service cost
and transition obligation, which
totaled $227&nbsp;million and $333&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. The additional minimum pension liability adjustments totaling
$786&nbsp;million and $1.6&nbsp;billion, net of tax, were recorded in accumulated other
comprehensive loss on our Consolidated Balance Sheets at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and
2002, respectively (see Note 13).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The accumulated benefit obligation for all our defined benefit pension plans
was $11.9&nbsp;billion and $10.1&nbsp;billion at September&nbsp;30, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. The following is information about our pension plans with an
accumulated benefit obligation in excess of plan assets (measured at September
30):
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We have implemented a limit on the amount we will pay for
postretirement medical benefits for employees who retire after November&nbsp;1,
1993. The assumed healthcare cost trend rate is assumed to decline
gradually to 5.25% by 2007 for health plan
costs not subject to this limit and to zero by 2006 for health
plan costs subject to the limit, and remain level thereafter.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Our 2003 assumptions reflect our October&nbsp;31, 2002 remeasurement of a
portion of our obligations and represent the weighted average of the
September&nbsp;30, 2002 and October&nbsp;31, 2002 assumptions.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The expected long-term rate of return on our plan assets was based on
plan-specific asset/liability investment studies performed by outside
consultants who used historical market return and volatility data with forward looking
estimates based on existing financial market conditions and forecasts. Modest
excess return expectations versus some market indices were incorporated into
the return projections based on the actively managed structure of our
investment program and its record of achieving such returns historically.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-43</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Assumed healthcare cost trend rates have a significant effect on the amounts
reported for the other postretirement benefit plans. A 1% change in the
healthcare cost trend rate used in measuring the accumulated postretirement
benefit obligation (APBO)&nbsp;for these plans at September&nbsp;30, 2003, would have the
following effects:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="83%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><FONT size="1"><B>(in millions)</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>1% Increase</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>1% Decrease</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD nowrap align="center"><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;8, 2003, President Bush signed into law the Medicare Act. The
impact of this law is not reflected in the tables above due to our September&nbsp;30
measurement date, which was prior to the enactment of this law. In compliance
with FSP 106-1, in 2004, we will make a one-time election to reflect the
estimated impact of the law immediately or to defer recognition until specific
authoritative guidance on accounting for the federal subsidy portion of the law
is issued. In either case, when specific guidance is issued, we could be
required to change previously reported financial information.
</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The investment strategy for pension plan assets is to utilize a diversified mix
of global public and private equity portfolios, public and private fixed income
portfolios, and private real estate and natural resource investments to earn
a long-term investment return that meets or exceeds a 9% annualized return target.
The overall asset mix of the portfolio is more heavily weighted in equity-like
investments, including portions of the bond portfolio which consist of
convertible and high yield securities. Active management strategies are
utilized throughout the program in an effort to realize investment returns in
excess of market indices. Also, option and currency overlay strategies are
used in an effort to generate modest amounts of additional income, and a bond
duration extension program utilizing fixed income derivatives is employed in an
effort to better align the market value movements of a portion of the pension
plan assets to the related pension plan liabilities.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-44</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Cash Flows</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We expect to contribute approximately $440&nbsp;million to our qualified defined
benefit pension plans in 2004. Benefit payments relating to our non-qualified
pension plans are expected to be approximately $60&nbsp;million in 2004 and funded
primarily from current assets.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our postretirement benefit plans are funded from current assets. We expect to
make benefit payments of $161&nbsp;million in relation to our postretirement benefit
plans in 2004.
</FONT>

</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Defined Contribution Pension Plans</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Delta Pilots Money Purchase Pension Plan (MPPP)</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We contribute 5% of covered pay to the MPPP for each eligible Delta pilot. The
MPPP is related to the Delta Pilots Retirement Plan. The defined benefit
pension payable to a pilot is reduced by the actuarial equivalent of the
accumulated account balance in the MPPP. During the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2003, 2002 and 2001, we recognized expense of $66&nbsp;million, $71&nbsp;million and $69
million, respectively, for this plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Delta Family-Care Savings Plan</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our Savings Plan includes an employee stock ownership plan (ESOP)&nbsp;feature.
Eligible employees may contribute a portion of their covered pay to the Savings
Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-45</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Prior to July&nbsp;1, 2001, we matched 50% of employee contributions with a maximum
employer contribution of 2% of a participant&#146;s covered pay for all
participants. Effective July&nbsp;1, 2001, the Savings Plan was amended to provide
all eligible Delta pilots with an employer contribution of 3% of their covered
pay to replace their former matching contribution. We make our contributions
for non-pilots and pilots by allocating Series&nbsp;B ESOP Convertible Preferred
Stock (ESOP Preferred Stock), common stock or cash to the Savings Plan. Our
contributions, which are recorded as salaries and related costs in our
Consolidated Statements of Operations, totaled $81&nbsp;million, $85&nbsp;million and $83
million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">When we adopted the ESOP in 1989, we sold 6,944,450 shares of ESOP Preferred
Stock to the Savings Plan for $500&nbsp;million. We have recorded unearned
compensation equal to the value of the shares of ESOP Preferred Stock not yet
allocated to participants&#146; accounts. We reduce the unearned compensation as
shares of ESOP Preferred Stock are allocated to participants&#146; accounts.
Dividends on unallocated shares of ESOP Preferred Stock are used for debt
service on the Savings Plan&#146;s ESOP Notes and are not considered dividends for
financial reporting purposes. Dividends on allocated shares of ESOP Preferred
Stock are credited to participants&#146; accounts and are considered dividends for
financial reporting purposes. Only allocated shares of ESOP Preferred Stock are
considered outstanding when we compute diluted earnings per share. At December
31, 2003, 3,817,884 shares of ESOP Preferred Stock were allocated to
participants&#146; accounts, and 2,021,824 shares were held by the ESOP for future
allocations. See Note 12 for information about changes to our ESOP Preferred
Stock dividend and redemption policies.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Other Plans</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">ASA, Comair and DAL Global Services, Inc., three of our wholly owned
subsidiaries, sponsor defined contribution retirement plans for eligible
employees. These plans did not have a material impact on our Consolidated
Financial Statements in 2003, 2002 and 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Postemployment Benefits</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We provide certain other welfare benefits to eligible former or inactive
employees after employment but before retirement, primarily as part of the
disability and survivorship plans.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Postemployment benefit expense (income)&nbsp;was $131&nbsp;million, $62&nbsp;million and $(23)
million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively. We
include the amount funded in excess of the liability in other noncurrent assets
on our Consolidated Balance Sheets. Future period expenses will vary based on
actual claims experience and the return on plan assets. Gains and losses occur
because actual experience differs from assumed experience. These gains and
losses are amortized over the average future service period of employees. We
also amortize differences in prior service costs resulting from amendments
affecting the benefits of retired and inactive employees.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-46</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 12. Common and Preferred Stock</B>
</FONT>
<DIV align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Stock Option and Other Stock-Based Award Plans</I></B>
</FONT></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">To more closely align the interests of directors, officers and other employees
with the interests of our shareowners, we maintain certain plans which provide
for the issuance of common stock in connection with the exercise of stock
options and for other stock-based awards. Stock options awarded under these
plans (1)&nbsp;have an exercise price equal to the fair value of the common stock on
the grant date; (2)&nbsp;become exercisable one to five years after the grant date;
and (3)&nbsp;expire up to 10&nbsp;years after the grant date. The following table
includes additional information about these plans as of December&nbsp;31, 2003:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="85%">

    <TD width="55%">&nbsp;</TD>
