</CENTER>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In 1996, shareowners approved broad-based pilot and non-pilot stock
option plans. Under these two plans, we granted eligible employees non-qualified stock options to purchase a total of 49.4&nbsp;million shares of
common stock in three approximately equal installments on October&nbsp;30,
1996, 1997 and 1998.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;25, 2000, shareowners approved this plan, which authorizes
the grant of stock options and a limited number of other stock awards. The
plan amends and restates a prior plan which was also approved by
shareowners. No awards have been, or will be, granted under the prior plan
on or after October&nbsp;25, 2000. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, there were 3.6&nbsp;million
shares of common stock reserved for awards (primarily non-qualified stock
options) that were outstanding under the prior plan. The current plan
provides that shares reserved for awards under the plans that are
forfeited, settled in cash rather than stock or withheld, plus shares
tendered to us in connection with such awards, may be added back to the
shares available for future grants. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, 14.4&nbsp;million
shares had been added back pursuant to that provision, including 11.0
million shares canceled under the stock option exchange program discussed
below.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;22, 1998, the Board of Directors approved this plan under
which each non-employee director may receive an annual grant of
non-qualified stock options. This plan provides that shares reserved for
awards that are forfeited may be added back to the shares available for
future grants.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(4)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In 1995, shareowners approved this plan, which provides that a portion of
each non-employee director&#146;s compensation for serving as a director will
be paid in shares of common stock. It also permits non-employee directors
to elect to receive all or a portion of their cash compensation for
service as a director in shares of common stock at current market prices.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On May&nbsp;28, 2003, we commenced, with shareowner approval, a stock option
exchange program (Exchange Program) for eligible employees in our broad-based
stock option plans and the Delta 2000 Performance Compensation Plan.
Approximately 45,000 eligible employees were offered the opportunity to
exchange their outstanding stock options with an exercise price of $25 per
share or more for a designated fewer number of replacement options with an
exercise price equal to the fair market value of the common stock on the grant
date of the replacement options. In accordance with the terms of the Exchange
Program, we canceled approximately 32&nbsp;million outstanding stock options on June
25, 2003 and issued, in exchange for the canceled options, approximately 12
million replacement options on December&nbsp;26, 2003. The exercise price of the
replacement options is $11.60, the closing price of our common stock on the
grant date. Members of our Board of Directors, including our Chief Executive
Officer, were not eligible to participate in the Exchange Program.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-47</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Payment of Dividends</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The determination to pay cash dividends on our ESOP Preferred Stock and our
common stock is at the discretion of our Board of Directors, and is also
subject to the provisions of Delaware General Corporation Law (Delaware Law).
Delaware law provides that a company may pay dividends on its stock only (1)
out of its &#147;surplus&#148;, which is generally defined as the excess of the company&#146;s
net assets over the aggregate par value of its issued stock, or (2)&nbsp;from its
net profits for the fiscal year in which the dividend is paid or from its net
profits for the preceding fiscal year.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In July 2003, our Board of Directors discontinued the payment of quarterly cash
dividends on our common stock due to the financial challenges facing Delta. We
had previously paid a quarterly dividend of $0.025 per common share.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Effective December 2003, our Board of Directors suspended indefinitely the
payment of dividends on our ESOP Preferred Stock to comply with Delaware law.
At December&nbsp;31, 2003, we had a negative &#147;surplus&#148; (as defined above) and we did
not have net profits in either of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 or 2002.
The terms of the ESOP Preferred Stock discussed
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-48</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">below provide for cumulative
dividends on that stock and prohibit the payment of dividends on our common
stock until all cumulative dividends on the ESOP Preferred Stock have been paid.
Unpaid dividends on the ESOP Preferred Stock will accrue without interest,
until paid, at a rate of $4.32 per share per year. At December&nbsp;31, 2003,
accumulated but unpaid dividends on the ESOP Preferred Stock totaled $13
million and are recorded in accounts payable, deferred credits and other
accrued liabilities on our Consolidated Balance Sheet.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>ESOP Preferred Stock</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Each outstanding share of ESOP Preferred Stock bears a cumulative cash dividend
of 6% per year of its stated value of $72.00; is convertible into 1.7155 shares
of common stock, which is equivalent to a conversion price of $41.97 per share;
and has a liquidation preference of $72.00, plus accrued and unpaid dividends.
The ESOP Preferred Stock generally votes together as a single class with the
common stock and has two votes per share. The conversion rate, conversion price
and voting rights of the ESOP Preferred Stock are subject to adjustment in
certain circumstances.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">All shares of ESOP Preferred Stock are held of record by the trustee of the
Delta Family-Care Savings Plan (see Note 11). At December&nbsp;31, 2003, 10,018,019
shares of common stock were reserved for issuance for the conversion of the
ESOP Preferred Stock.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We are generally required to redeem shares of ESOP Preferred Stock (1)&nbsp;to
provide for distributions of the accounts of Savings Plan participants who
terminate employment with us and request a distribution and (2)&nbsp;to implement
annual diversification elections by Savings Plan participants who are at least
age 55 and have participated in the Savings Plan for at least 10&nbsp;years. In
these circumstances, shares of ESOP Preferred Stock are redeemable at a price
equal to the greater of (1) $72.00 per share or (2)&nbsp;the fair value of the
shares of common stock issuable upon conversion of the ESOP Preferred Stock to
be redeemed, plus, in either case, accrued and unpaid dividends on such shares
of ESOP Preferred Stock (Redemption Price). Under the terms of the ESOP
Preferred Stock, we may pay the Redemption Price in cash, shares of common
stock (valued at fair market value), or in a combination thereof.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Delaware law, however, prohibits a company from redeeming or purchasing its
stock for cash or other property, unless the company has sufficient &#147;surplus&#148;.
As discussed above, at December&nbsp;31, 2003, we had a negative &#147;surplus&#148;.
Accordingly, effective December 2003, our Board of Directors changed the form
of payment we use to redeem shares of the ESOP Preferred Stock when redemptions
are required under our Delta Family-Care Savings Plan. For the indefinite
future, we will pay the Redemption Price in shares of our common stock rather
than in cash.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Shareowner Rights Plan</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Shareowner Rights Plan is designed to protect shareowners against attempts
to acquire Delta that do not offer an adequate purchase price to all
shareowners, or are otherwise not in the best interest of Delta and our
shareowners. Under the plan, each outstanding share of common stock is
accompanied by one-half of a preferred stock purchase right. Each whole right
entitles the holder to purchase 1/100 of a share of Series&nbsp;D Junior
Participating Preferred Stock at an exercise price of $300, subject to
adjustment.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-49</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The rights become exercisable only after a person acquires, or makes a tender
or exchange offer that would result in the person acquiring, beneficial
ownership of 15% or more of our common stock. If a person acquires beneficial
ownership of 15% or more of our common stock, each right will entitle its
holder (other than the acquiring person) to exercise his rights to purchase our
common stock having a market value of twice the exercise price.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">If a person acquires beneficial interest of 15% or more of our common stock and
(1)&nbsp;we are involved in a merger or other business combination in which we are
not the surviving corporation, or (2)&nbsp;we sell more than 50% of our assets or
earning power, then each right will entitle its holder (other than the
acquiring person) to exercise their rights to purchase common stock of the
acquiring company having a market value of twice the exercise price.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The rights expire on November&nbsp;4, 2006. We may redeem the rights for $0.01 per
right at any time before a person becomes the beneficial owner of 15% or more
of our common stock. We may amend the rights in any respect so long as the
rights are redeemable. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2,250,000 shares of preferred
stock were reserved for issuance under the Shareowner Rights Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 13. Comprehensive Income (Loss)</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Comprehensive income (loss)&nbsp;includes (1)&nbsp;reported net income (loss); (2)&nbsp;the
additional minimum pension liability; (3)&nbsp;effective unrealized gains and losses
on fuel derivative instruments that qualify for hedge accounting; and (4)
unrealized gains and losses on marketable equity securities. The following
table shows our comprehensive loss for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002
and 2001:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We estimate that effective gains of $34&nbsp;million, net of tax, will be realized
during 2004 as (1)&nbsp;fuel hedge contracts settle and (2)&nbsp;the related aircraft
fuel purchases being hedged are consumed and recognized in expense. See Note 4

</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 14. Geographic Information</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">SFAS No.&nbsp;131, &#147;Disclosures about Segments of an Enterprise and Related
Information&#148; (SFAS 131), requires us to disclose certain information about our
operating segments. Operating segments are defined as components of an
enterprise with separate financial information which is
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-51</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">evaluated regularly by the chief operating decision-maker and is used in
resource allocation and performance assessments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We are managed as a single business unit that provides air transportation for
passengers and cargo. This allows us to benefit from an integrated revenue
pricing and route network that includes Delta-Mainline (including Song), ASA
and Comair. The flight equipment of all three carriers is combined to form one
fleet which is deployed through a single route scheduling system. When making
resource allocation decisions, our chief operating decision maker evaluates
flight profitability data, which considers aircraft type and route economics,
but gives no weight to the financial impact of the resource allocation decision
on an individual carrier basis. Our objective in making resource allocation
decisions is to maximize our consolidated financial results, not the individual
results of Delta-Mainline (including Song), ASA and Comair.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Operating revenues are assigned to a specific geographic region based on the
origin, flight path and destination of each flight segment. Our operating
revenues by geographic region for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and
2001 are summarized in the following table:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="55%">

across geographic markets. Accordingly, assets are not allocated to specific
geographic regions.

pension settlements and related items, net on our Consolidated Statement of
Operations, as follows:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>2002</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2002, we recorded net charges totaling $439&nbsp;million ($277&nbsp;million net of
tax, or $2.25 diluted earnings per share) in restructuring, asset writedowns,
pension settlements and related items, net on our Consolidated Statement of
Operations, as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Fleet Changes</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">During 2002, we made significant changes in our fleet plan (1)&nbsp;to reduce
costs through fleet simplification and capacity reductions and (2)&nbsp;to
decrease capital expenditures through aircraft deferrals. These actions
resulted in $225&nbsp;million in net asset impairments and other charges which
are discussed below.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">During the September 2002 quarter, we recorded an impairment charge, shown
in the table below, related to 59 owned B-727 aircraft. The impairment of 23
B-727 aircraft used in operations, at the time of the impairment analysis,
resulted from a further reduction in their estimated future cash flows and
fair values since our impairment review in 2001. The impairment of 36 B-727
aircraft held for sale resulted from a further decline in their fair values
less the cost to sell since our impairment review in 2001. The aircraft held
for sale were sold as part of our fleet simplification plan during 2003; the
net book value of these aircraft was included in other noncurrent assets on
our Consolidated Balance Sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2002, and was not material.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">During the September 2002 quarter, we also decided to temporarily remove our
MD-11 aircraft from service beginning in early 2003. As a result of this
decision, we recorded an impairment charge, shown in the table below,
related to our eight owned MD-11 aircraft. This charge reflects the further
reduction in estimated future cash flows and fair values of these aircraft
since our impairment review in 2001. The MD-11 aircraft were replaced on
international routes by B-767-300ER aircraft that had been used in our
domestic system. We used smaller mainline aircraft to replace the
B-767-300ER aircraft on domestic routes, thereby reducing our domestic
capacity.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">During the December 2002 quarter, we decided to return to service, beginning
in 2003, nine leased B-737-300 aircraft. This decision was based on (1)
capacity and operating cost considerations and (2)&nbsp;our inability to sublease
the B-737-300 aircraft due to the difficult business environment facing the
airline industry after September&nbsp;11, 2001. As discussed below, during the
June 2001 quarter, we decided to remove the B-737-300 aircraft from service
and recorded a reserve for future lease payments less estimated sublease
income. Due</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">The fair value of aircraft used in operations was determined using
third party appraisals.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Charges related to the writedown of the related spare parts inventory
to their net realizable value.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2"><SUP>(3)</SUP></FONT></TD>

December&nbsp;31, 2003.</FONT></TD>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Workforce Reductions</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recorded a $127&nbsp;million charge related to our decision in October 2002 to
reduce staffing by up to approximately 8,000 jobs across all workgroups,
excluding pilots, to further reduce operating costs. We offered eligible
non-pilot employees several programs, including voluntary severance, leaves
of absence and early retirement. Approximately 3,900 employees elected to
participate in one of these programs. Involuntary reductions were expected
to affect approximately 4,000 employees (see Note 16).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">The total charge includes (1) $51&nbsp;million for costs associated with the
voluntary programs that were recorded as special termination benefits under
our pension and postretirement medical benefit obligations (see Note 11) and
(2) $76&nbsp;million for severance and related costs.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Surplus Pilots and Grounded Aircraft</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recorded $93&nbsp;million in expenses for the temporary carrying cost of
surplus pilots and grounded aircraft related to our capacity reductions
which became effective on November&nbsp;1, 2001. This cost also included related
requalification training and relocation costs for certain pilots.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-54</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>




<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Other</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recorded (1)&nbsp;a $23&nbsp;million gain related to the adjustment of certain
prior year restructuring reserves based on revised estimates of remaining
costs; (2)&nbsp;a $14&nbsp;million charge associated with our decision to close
certain leased facilities; and (3)&nbsp;a $3&nbsp;million charge related to other
items (see Note 16).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>2001</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In 2001, we recorded charges totaling $1.1&nbsp;billion ($695&nbsp;million net of tax, or
$5.63 diluted earnings per share) in restructuring, asset writedowns, pension
settlements and related items, net on our Consolidated Statement of Operations,
as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Workforce Reductions</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recorded a $566&nbsp;million charge relating to our decision in 2001 to reduce
staffing across all workgroups due to the capacity reductions we implemented
as a result of the September&nbsp;11 terrorist attacks. We offered eligible
employees several programs, including voluntary severance, leaves of absence
and early retirement. Approximately 10,000 employees elected to participate
in one of the voluntary programs. Involuntary reductions were expected to
affect up to approximately 1,700 employees &#151; up to 1,400 pilots and 300
employees from other workgroups.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">The total charge includes $475&nbsp;million for costs associated with the early
retirement and certain voluntary leave of absence programs which are
recorded as special termination benefits under our pension and
postretirement medical benefit obligations (see Note 11). The remaining $91
million relates to severance and related costs.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Fleet Changes</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">As a result of the effects of the September&nbsp;11 terrorist attacks on our
business and the related decline in aircraft values, we recorded $286
million in asset writedowns. These writedowns include (1)&nbsp;the impairment of
16 MD-90 and eight MD-11 owned aircraft, which reflects further reductions
in the estimated future cash flows and fair values of these aircraft since
our impairment review in 1999, as well as a revised schedule for retiring
these aircraft; (2)&nbsp;charges related to the accelerated retirement of 40
owned B-727 aircraft by 2003; and (3)&nbsp;the writedown to fair value of 18
owned L-1011 aircraft. These charges are summarized in the table below:</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="55%">

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#eeeeee">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">MD-90</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In addition, we recorded a $71&nbsp;million reserve related to our decision to
remove nine leased B-737-300 aircraft from service to more closely align
capacity and demand, and to improve scheduling and operating efficiency. The
reserve consisted of future lease payments for these aircraft less estimated
sublease income. We also recorded an additional $6&nbsp;million charge for the
writedown to net realizable value of related aircraft spare parts.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recorded $30&nbsp;million in expenses for the temporary carrying cost of
surplus pilots and grounded aircraft related to our capacity reductions
which became effective on November&nbsp;1, 2001. This cost also included related
requalification training and relocation costs for certain pilots.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">We recorded $160&nbsp;million in charges that included (1) $81&nbsp;million
related to the write-off of previously capitalized amounts that would
provide no future economic benefit due to our decision to cancel or delay
certain airport and technology projects following September&nbsp;11, 2001; (2)
$63&nbsp;million related to contract termination costs; (3) $9&nbsp;million related to
the write-off of certain receivables, primarily those of foreign air
carriers and other related businesses, that we believe became uncollectible
as a result of those businesses&#146; weakened financial condition after
September&nbsp;11, 2001; and (4) $7&nbsp;million related to our decision to close
certain facilities.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The leased aircraft reserve represented future lease payments under operating
leases for nine B-737-300 aircraft previously removed from service prior to the
lease expiration date, less estimated sublease income. Due to changes in our
fleet plan during the December 2002 quarter, we (1)&nbsp;reversed the remaining $56
million balance of this reserve and (2)&nbsp;returned these aircraft to service in
2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the facilities and other reserve represents costs related
primarily to (1)&nbsp;future lease payments for facilities closures and (2)&nbsp;contract
termination fees. During 2003, we recorded a $9&nbsp;million adjustment to prior
year reserves based on revised estimates of remaining costs primarily due to
changes in certain facility lease terms. During 2002, we recorded a $14&nbsp;million
adjustment to prior year reserves based on revised estimates of remaining
costs.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The severance and related costs reserve represents future payments associated
with our 2002 and 2001 voluntary and involuntary workforce reduction programs.
At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the remaining $5&nbsp;million balance related to the 2002
workforce reduction programs represents severance and medical benefits for
employees who received severance or are participating in certain leave of
absence programs. Approximately half of the remaining balance is for
international employees that will be paid in accordance with local country laws
and regulations. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the remaining $1&nbsp;million balance related to the 2001
workforce reduction
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-57</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">programs primarily consists of severance for international
employees that will be paid in accordance with local country laws and
regulations. During 2003, we recorded a $21&nbsp;million adjustment to prior year
reserves based upon revised estimates of remaining costs primarily due to fewer
employee reductions under our 2002 involuntary workforce reduction program than
originally anticipated because of higher than expected reductions from
attrition and retirements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">During 2002, we recorded a $9&nbsp;million adjustment to the 2001 severance and
related costs reserve based on revised estimates of the remaining costs,
including (1)&nbsp;the adjustment of medical benefits for certain employees
participating in the leave of absence programs who returned to the workforce
earlier than originally scheduled and (2)&nbsp;the change in the number of pilot
furloughs from up to 1,400 to approximately 1,100.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">See Note 15 for additional information related to the charges discussed above.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 17. Equity Investments</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>WORLDSPAN, L.P. (Worldspan)</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On June&nbsp;30, 2003, we sold our 40% equity investment in Worldspan, which
operates and markets a computer reservation system for the travel industry. In
exchange for the sale of our equity interest, we received (1) $285&nbsp;million in
cash and (2)&nbsp;a $45&nbsp;million subordinated promissory note, which bears interest
at 10% per annum and matures in 2012. As a result of this transaction, we
recorded a gain of $279&nbsp;million ($176&nbsp;million net of tax) in other income
(expense)&nbsp;on our 2003 Consolidated Statement of Operations. In addition, we
will receive credits totaling approximately $125&nbsp;million, which will be
recognized ratably as a reduction of costs through 2012, for future
Worldspan-provided services. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the carrying and fair value
of the subordinated promissory note was $38&nbsp;million, which reflects a writedown
resulting from a decrease in its fair value. This note is classified as a
trading security under SFAS 115 (see Note 1).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our equity earnings from this investment totaled $18&nbsp;million, $43&nbsp;million and
$19&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.
We also received cash dividends from Worldspan of $44&nbsp;million, $40&nbsp;million and
$70&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002, and 2001,
respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, our Worldspan investment of $57&nbsp;million was
recorded in investments in associated companies on our Consolidated Balance
Sheet.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Worldspan provides computer reservation and related services for us, which
totaled approximately $90&nbsp;million for the six-months ended June&nbsp;30, 2003 and
approximately $180&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. As discussed
above, we sold our equity interest in Worldspan on June&nbsp;30, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Orbitz, Inc. (Orbitz)</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Prior to December 2003, we had an 18% ownership and voting interest in Orbitz,
which we accounted for under the equity method. We used the equity method
because we had the ability to exercise significant influence, but not control,
over the financial and operating policies of Orbitz. This influence was
evidenced by, among other things, our right to appoint two of our senior
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-58</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">officers to the 11 member Board of Managers of Orbitz, which enabled us to
participate in Orbitz&#146;s financial and operating decisions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">During December 2003, Orbitz completed its initial public offering and the
founding airlines of Orbitz, including us, sold a portion of their Orbitz
shares. We received $33&nbsp;million in cash from our sale of Orbitz shares.
Additionally, we recorded (1)&nbsp;a SAB 51 gain of $18&nbsp;million, net of tax, in
additional paid-in capital on our Consolidated Balance Sheet (see Note 1 for
our SAB 51 accounting policy); (2)&nbsp;a $28&nbsp;million gain ($17&nbsp;million net of tax)
in other income (expense)&nbsp;on our Consolidated Statement of Operations resulting
from our sale of Orbitz shares; and (3)&nbsp;a $4&nbsp;million loss ($2&nbsp;million net of
tax) in other income (expense)&nbsp;on our Consolidated Statement of Operations
resulting from previously unrecognized Orbitz losses since our recorded
investment in Orbitz was zero prior to its initial public offering.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Upon completion of the transactions discussed above, we have a 13% ownership
interest in Orbitz and an 18% voting interest. We continue to account for this
investment under the equity method due to, among other things, our continuing
18% voting interest and our right to appoint one of our senior officers to the
nine member Board of Directors of Orbitz, which enables us to exercise
significant influence over Orbitz&#146;s financial and operating decisions. At
December&nbsp;31, 2003, our investment in Orbitz was $21&nbsp;million and is recorded in
investments in associated companies on our Consolidated Balance Sheet. At
December&nbsp;31, 2002, our investment balance was zero since our equity investment
had been reduced to zero as a result of our share of Orbitz&#146;s net losses.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 18. Earnings (Loss) per Share</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We calculate basic earnings (loss)&nbsp;per share by dividing the net income (loss)
available to common shareowners by the weighted average number of common shares
outstanding. Diluted earnings (loss)&nbsp;per share includes the dilutive effects of
stock options and convertible securities. To the extent stock options and
convertible securities are anti-dilutive, they are excluded from the
calculation of diluted earnings (loss)&nbsp;per share. The following table shows our
computation of basic and diluted loss per share:
</FONT>

was greater than the average price of our common stock; (2)&nbsp;7.3&nbsp;million, 6.9
million and 6.5&nbsp;million additional shares that may be issued in certain
circumstances, respectively, because their effect on loss per share was
anti-dilutive; and (3)&nbsp;the

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">shares issuable upon conversion of our 8.00% Notes due 2023 since the
contingent conditions for conversion have not been met (see Note 6).
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 19. Government Compensation and Reimbursements</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Appropriations Act Reimbursements</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;16, 2003, President Bush signed into law the Emergency Wartime
Supplemental Appropriations Act (Appropriations Act), which provides for, among
other things:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Payments for Certain Security Fees. </I>Payments totaling $2.3&nbsp;billion
from the U.S. government to U.S. air carriers for the reimbursement of
certain passenger and air carrier security fees.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Executive Compensation Limits. </I>A requirement that certain airlines
which receive the security fee payments described above enter into a
contract with the Transportation Security Administration (TSA)&nbsp;agreeing
that the air carrier will not provide total cash compensation (as defined in
the Appropriations Act) during the 12-month period beginning April&nbsp;1,
2003 to certain executive officers during its fiscal year 2002 in an
amount greater than the annual salary paid to that officer with respect
to the air carrier&#146;s fiscal year 2002. If it violates this agreement,
the air carrier is required to repay its security fee payments
described above. We are subject to this requirement and have entered
into the required contract with the TSA.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Compensation for Strengthening Flight Deck Doors. </I>Payments
totaling $100&nbsp;million from the U.S. government to compensate air
carriers for the direct costs associated with the strengthening of
flight deck doors and locks on aircraft.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Suspension of Passenger and Air Carrier Security Fees. </I>The
suspension of the TSA&#146;s collection of passenger and air carrier
security fees during the period beginning June&nbsp;1, 2003 and ending
September&nbsp;30, 2003.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2"><I>Insurance. </I>An extension for one year until August 2004, with a
possible extension to December&nbsp;31, 2004 at the discretion of the
Secretary of Transportation, of the U.S. government&#146;s obligation to
sell war-risk insurance to air carriers.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">During 2003, we received payments under the Appropriations Act totaling (1)
$398&nbsp;million as reimbursement for passenger and air carrier security fees,
which was recorded as a reduction of operating expenses in our 2003
Consolidated Statement of Operations and (2) $13&nbsp;million related to the
strengthening of flight deck doors, which was recorded as a reduction to
previously capitalized costs.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Stabilization Act Compensation</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;22, 2001, the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization
Act (Stabilization Act) became effective. The Stabilization Act was intended
to preserve the viability of the U.S. air transportation system following the
terrorist attacks on September&nbsp;11, 2001 by, among other things, (1)&nbsp;providing
for payments from the U.S. Government totaling $5&nbsp;billion to compensate U.S.
air carriers for losses incurred from September&nbsp;11, 2001 through December&nbsp;31,
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-60</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">2001 as a
result of the September&nbsp;11 terrorist attacks and (2)&nbsp;permitting the Secretary
of Transportation to sell insurance to U.S. air carriers.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our allocated portion of compensation under the Stabilization Act was $668
million. Due to uncertainties regarding the U.S. government&#146;s calculation of
compensation, we recognized $634&nbsp;million of this amount in our 2001
Consolidated Statement of Operations. We recognized the remaining $34&nbsp;million
of compensation in our 2002 Consolidated Statement of Operations. We received
$112&nbsp;million and $556&nbsp;million in cash for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and
2001, respectively, under the Stabilization Act.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Subsequent to September&nbsp;11, 2001, aviation insurers significantly reduced the
maximum amount of insurance coverage available to commercial air carriers for
liability to persons (other than employees or passengers) for claims resulting
from acts of terrorism, war or similar events. At the same time, aviation
insurers significantly increased the premiums for such coverage and for
aviation insurance in general. Under the Stabilization Act, the U.S. government
is providing U.S. airlines with war-risk insurance to cover losses to
passengers, third parties (ground damage) and the aircraft hull. This coverage
extends through August 2004, with a possible extension to December&nbsp;31, 2004 at
the discretion of the Secretary of Transportation, but the coverage may not be
extended beyond that time. We expect that if the U.S. government fails to renew
the war-risk insurance that it provides, we will be required to replace such
coverage commercially or consider other alternatives. There can be no assurance
that such commercially provided war-risk insurance coverage will be adequate to
protect our risk of loss from future acts of terrorism or will be provided on
terms that will not have a material adverse impact on our Consolidated
Financial Statements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 20. Related Party Transaction</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The Delta Employees Credit Union (DECU)&nbsp;is an independent entity that is
chartered to provide banking and financial services to our employees, former
employees and certain relatives of these persons. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had
a $71&nbsp;million liability to DECU recorded in accounts payable, deferred credits
and other accrued liabilities on our Consolidated Balance Sheet. The liability
resulted from a timing difference in funding a portion of our 2002&nbsp;year end
payroll and is reflected as a non-cash transaction on our 2002 Consolidated
Statement of Cash Flows. We paid the liability on January&nbsp;2, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-61</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Note 22. Subsequent Events</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Convertible Senior Notes (2-7/8% Notes)</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In February 2004, we issued $325&nbsp;million principal amount of 2-7/8% Notes due
2024. Holders may convert their 2-7/8% Notes into shares of our common stock
at a conversion rate of 73.6106 shares of common stock per $1,000 principal
amount of 2-7/8% Notes, subject to adjustment in certain circumstances, which
is equivalent to a conversion price of approximately $13.59 per share of common
stock, if:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">during any calendar quarter after March&nbsp;31, 2004, the last reported
sale price of our common stock for at least 20 trading days during the
period of 30 consecutive trading days ending on the last trading day of
the immediately preceding calendar quarter is greater than or equal to
130% of the conversion price per share of our common stock;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">the trading price of the 2-7/8% Notes falls below a specified threshold;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">we call the 2-7/8% Notes for redemption; or</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">specified corporate transactions occur.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-62</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>




<P align="left"><FONT size="2">We may redeem all or some of the 2-7/8% Notes for cash at any time after
February&nbsp;21, 2009, at a redemption price equal to the principal amount of the
2-7/8% Notes to be redeemed plus any accrued and unpaid interest.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Holders may require us to repurchase their 2-7/8% Notes for cash on February
18, 2009, 2014 and 2019, or in other specified circumstances involving the
exchange, conversion or acquisition of all or substantially all of our common
stock, at a purchase price equal to the principal amount of the 2-7/8% Notes to
be purchased plus any accrued and unpaid interest. At February&nbsp;27, 2003,
23,923,445 shares of common stock were reserved for issuance for the conversion
of the 2-7/8% Notes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Aircraft Acquisition</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;27, 2004, we entered
into an agreement to purchase 32 CRJ-200 aircraft to
be delivered in 2005. In conjunction with this agreement, we entered into a
facility with a third party to finance, on a secured basis at the time of
acquisition, the future deliveries of these regional jet aircraft. Borrowings
under this facility (1)&nbsp;will be due in installments for 15&nbsp;years after the date
of borrowing and (2)&nbsp;bear interest at LIBOR plus a margin.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Other Financing Arrangements</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In January 2004, we entered into financing arrangements under which we borrowed
a total of $208&nbsp;million. These borrowings are due in installments through
February 2020; are secured by six CRJ-200 and seven CRJ-700 aircraft; and bear
interest at LIBOR plus a margin. A portion of the proceeds from these
borrowings was used to repay $151&nbsp;million of outstanding interim financing for
six CRJ-200 and three CRJ-700 aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Fuel Contract Settlements</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">In February 2004, we settled all of our fuel hedge contracts prior to their
scheduled settlement dates. As a result of these transactions, we received $83
million in cash, which represented the fair value of these contracts
at the date of settlement. In accordance with SFAS 133, effective gains of
$82&nbsp;million
will be recorded in accumulated other comprehensive loss until the related fuel
purchases, which were being hedged, are consumed and recognized in expense during
2004. These gains will then be recorded as a reduction in fuel expense on our
Consolidated Statements of Operations. The ineffective portion of the hedges
and the time value component of these contracts totaling
$17&nbsp;million will be recognized in the March 2004 quarter as a fair value adjustment
of SFAS 133 derivatives in other income (expense)&nbsp;on our Consolidated
Statements of Operations. See Note 4 and 13 for additional information about
our fuel hedge contracts.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-63</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

impacted by certain events, as discussed below:

postretirement related charges. In December 2002, we recorded a charge
related to our 2002 workforce reduction programs. See Note 15 for
additional information about these charges.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

U.S. government for certain passenger and air carrier security fees.

Stabilization Act compensation. See Note 19 for additional information
about these government reimbursements and compensation.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

investments. These gains primarily related to (1)&nbsp;the sale of our
investment in Worldspan in June 2003 and (2)&nbsp;our sale of Orbitz shares
in December 2003. See Note 17 for additional information about these
sales.</FONT></TD>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>The following is a copy of the audit report previously issued by Arthur
Andersen LLP in connection with Delta&#146;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. This audit report has not been
reissued by Arthur Andersen LLP.</I></B>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT PUBLIC ACCOUNTANTS ON SCHEDULE</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">To Delta Air Lines, Inc.:



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited, in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in
the United States, the consolidated financial statements included in Delta Air
Lines, Inc.&#146;s annual report to shareowners incorporated by reference in this
Form 10-K and have issued our report thereon dated January&nbsp;23, 2002. Our
audits were made for the purpose of forming an opinion on those statements
taken as a whole. The schedule listed in the accompanying index is the
responsibility of the company&#146;s management, is presented for purposes of
complying with the Securities and Exchange Commission&#146;s rules, and is not part
of the basic financial statements. The schedule has been subjected to the
auditing procedures applied in the audits of the basic financial statements
and, in our opinion, fairly states in all material respects the financial data
required to be set forth therein in relation to the basic consolidated
financial statements taken as a whole.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">/s/ ARTHUR ANDERSEN LLP


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Atlanta, Georgia<BR>
January&nbsp;23, 2002


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;
</DIV>

<P>

    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">(a)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Represents write-off of accounts considered to be uncollectible, less
collections.</TD>
</TR>

<TR><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="right">(b)</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="96%">Represents payments made.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
